feature.feature_help_text: Assigns the logical COM Port number and associated default resources to the selected physical serial port This setting may be overwritten by your OS.

Assigns the logical COM Port address and associated default resources to be used by the Virtual Serial Port (VSP). The VSP allows the ILO Management Controller to appear as a physical serial port in order to support BIOS Serial Console and Operating Systems serial console.

feature.feature_warning_text: Note: When enabling Network boot support for an embedded NIC, the NIC will not show up in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) until the next reboot.
Note: When enabling Network boot support for an embedded NIC, the NIC will not show up in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) until the next reboot.
Note: When enabling Network boot support for an embedded NIC, the NIC will not show up in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) until the next reboot.
Note: When enabling Network boot support for an embedded NIC, the NIC will not show up in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) until the next reboot.

feature.feature_help_text:
Advanced Memory Protection provides additional memory protection beyond ECC (error checking and correcting).
Advanced ECC provides the largest memory capacity to the operating system.
Online Spare memory will allow a system to automatically map out a group of memory that is receiving excessive correctable memory errors. This memory will be replaced by a spare group of memory.

option.option_name: Online Spare with Advanced ECC Support

feature.feature_help_text: USB Enabled: enables all USB ports and embedded devices. External USB Ports Disabled: only external USB ports are disabled.
This option allows the user to prevent the system from booting all USB devices connected to the server. This option will also disable booting iLO virtual media.

This option allows the user to select which one of three USB removable flash media (Internal SD Card, Internal Drive Key, or External Drive Key) to boot first if multiple media are present. Please note that the system is limited to two bootable removable USB flash media, and due to the order in which USB devices are enumerated, the system will not boot to the external drive key even if selected as first when all three types of media are present. In addition, this option does not override the device boot order selected in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) option.
This option allows the user to disable the BIOS enumeration of USB Drive Keys. When disabled, USB drive keys will not be available in a pre-boot environment.

Enables the HW portion of a feature that allows systems to be protected against malicious code and viruses. In combination with an OS that supports this feature, memory is marked as non-executable unless the location explicitly contains executable code. Some viruses attempt to insert and execute code from non-executable memory locations. These attacks are intercepted and an exception is raised.
When enabled, a Virtual Machine Manager supporting this feature can utilize hardware capabilities provided by Intel`s Virtualization Technology.

This feature allows disabling of logical processor cores on processors supporting Intel`s Hyper-Threading Technology This option may improve overall performance for applications that will benefit from higher processor core count.

This feature allows disabling of processor cores using Intel`s Core Multi-Processing (CMP) Technology. This option allows disabling a specific number of the cores on each physical processor. This option has the following potential uses: Reduce processor power usage and potentially improve performance/watt with some applications; improve overall performance for applications that will benefit from higher performance cores rather than more processing cores; address issues with software that is licensed on a per-core basis. The value entered should be the number of enabled cores per socket.
feature.feature_warning_text: Please enter the number of cores to be ENABLED per processor socket. Valid values are 1 to 08 where 1 indicates that one core will be ENABLED per processor socket. A value of 0 is invalid as the minimum number of enabled cores per processor socket is 1. Press any key to allow entering the number of ENABLED cores.

feature.feature_help_text: Turbo Boost Technology is a processor feature which allows the processor to transition to a higher frequency than the processor`s rated speed if the processor has available power headroom and is within temperature specifications.
When enabled, a Virtual Machine Manager supporting this feature can utilize hardware capabilities provided by Intel`s Virtualization Technology for Directed I/O.
Selects the default state of NUMLOCK key.

This option allows configuring of the embedded chipset SATA controller. When selecting the Advanced Host Controller Interface (AHCI) or RAID, ensure that the proper Operating System drivers are used to ensure correct operating.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Enabling RAID will result in data loss or data corruption on existing SATA drives. Please backup all drives before enabling this feature.

option.option_name: Enable Dynamic HP Smart Array B120i RAID Support

feature.feature_help_text: Enabling this option allows the server to turn on the Drive Write Cache in the ATA hard drive. This feature will provide greater drive performance but could cause data corruption during an unexpected power loss or shutdown.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Enabling Drive Write Cache may result in data loss or data corruption if an unexpected power loss occurs.

feature.feature_name: HP Dynamic Smart Array B320i RAID Controller
feature.feature_help_text: Allows the user to enable HP RAID functionality on the embedded/optional SAS controller.
feature.feature_warning_text: Enabling RAID functionality may result in data loss or data corruption on existing drives. Please backup all drives before enabling this feature.

feature.feature_help_text: Multi Processor Specification Table/APIC Setting is used for interrupt routing. Certain unsupported operating systems may require setting the Multi Processor Specification Table Mode to APIC Disabled.
This option allows the server to switch back to a previous ROM image. The backup image will be the ROM image that was being used prior to the last flash event.
Allows generating an NMI via the NMI button/jumper.
Controls the Virtual Install Disk. The Virtual Install Disk may contain drivers specific to this server that an OS may use during installation.

This option allows the user to disable the default PCI Bus setting where each expansion slot is provided an extra PCI Bus number. By default, the System ROM will pad one PCI bus per expansion slot to allow expansion cards with PCI-PCI bridges to not effect current bus numbering schemes. Disabling this option works around issues with certain expansion cards. It is not recommended this option be disabled unless a specific issue has been seen.
This option allows disabling the display of the Logo during system boot. This is an aesthetic modification only. This option does not affect system boot times.
This option allows the disabling of the POST One Time Boot F11 Prompt.

This option selects the level of Consistent Device Naming. On supported operating systems, NIC ports will be named based on their location in the system. "CDN Support for LOMs Only" will only name Embedded NICs and FlexibleLOMs (not NICs in slots). Note that existing NIC connections will retain their original name until reinstalled under the OS environment.

This option allows the user to disable the Network Boot Retry Support. By default, the System ROM will attempt to boot the Network device (i.e. PXE device) up to 20 times before falling through to the next IPL Device.

feature.feature_name: Reset on Boot Device Not Found
feature.feature_help_text: This option controls the System ROM logic of retrying bootable devices listed in the Standard Boot Order (IPL) if no bootable media is found. When set to Enabled, the System ROM will reset the platform after one attempt through the Standard Boot Order (IPL). When disabled, the System ROM will continually loop through the Standard Boot Order (IPL).
This option allows a user to disable HP Expansion Cards from delaying during POST and waiting on user input to enter Expansion Card Setup Utilities.

By default, the System ROM will disable the embedded video controller when an optional video controller is installed in the system. This option allows for the embedded video controller to remain enabled so that iLO remote video still functions or for dual head video support.

option.option_name: Optional Video Primary, Embedded Video Disabled
Optional Video Primary, Embedded Video Secondary
Embedded Video Primary, Optional Video Secondary

feature.feature_help_text: This feature allows the user to select the fan cooling solution for the system. Optimal cooling provides the most efficient solution by configuring fan speeds to the minimum required to provide adequately cooling. Increased Cooling will run fans at higher speeds to provide additional cooling. Increased Cooling should be selected when non-HP storage controllers are cabled to the embedded hard drive cage, or if the system is experiencing thermal issues that cannot be resolved in another manner.

This option allows the disabling of a processor prefetch feature. In very limited cases, setting this option to Disabled may improve performance. In the vast majority of cases, the default value of Enabled provides better performance. Users should only disable this option after performing application benchmarking to verify improved performance in their environment. This option is sometimes called the MLC Streamer Prefetcher.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Disabling this option is NOT recommended and typically degrades system performance. See F1 Help or RBSU Users Guide for more information.

feature.feature_help_text: This option allows the disabling of a processor prefetch feature. In very limited cases, setting this option to Disabled may improve performance. In the vast majority of cases, the default value of Enabled provides better performance. Users should only disable this option after performing application benchmarking to verify improved performance in their environment. This option is sometimes called the MLC Spatial Prefetcher.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Disabling this option is NOT recommended and typically degrades system performance. See F1 Help or RBSU Users Guide for more information.

feature.feature_help_text: This option allows the disabling of a processor prefetch feature. In very limited cases, setting this option to Disabled may improve performance. In the vast majority of cases, the default value of Enabled provides better performance. Users should only disable this option after performing application benchmarking to verify improved performance in their environment.

This option allows the disabling of a processor prefetch feature. In very limited cases, setting this option to Disabled may improve performance. In the vast majority of cases, the default value of Enabled provides better performance. Users should only disable this option after performing application benchmarking to verify improved performance in their environment.

Enabling Node Interleaving disables the NUMA architecture properties of this system. All operating systems supported by this platform support NUMA architectures. In the majority of cases, optimum performance is obtained by disabling Node Interleaving. When this option is enabled, memory addresses will be interleaved across the memory installed for each processor. Some workloads may see improved performance when this option is enabled.
feature.feature_warning_text: Caution: Enabling Node Interleaving may impact operating system performance. Enabling Node Interleaving requires all nodes to have equal memory sizes.

feature.feature_help_text: This option enables certain networking devices to improve performance by utilizing Intel`s DMA engine to offload network activity. Please consult network adapater documentation for more details.
This option allows the locking of the Asset Tag information When set to lock, the Asset Tag will NOT be erased if the default system settings are restored.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Choosing the Lock option will lock/protect the Asset Tag. The Asset Tag will NOT be erased if default system settings are restored.

feature.feature_help_text: This option provides the capability to enable or disable SR-IOV (Single Root I/O Virtualization).

Combined Channel Mode provides maximum data protection by allowing multiple-bit memory errors to be corrected in certain instances not possible in normal Advanced ECC Modes. Please see user documentation for memory installation rules for Combined Channel Mode.

This ACPI SLIT (System Locality Information Table) describes the relative access times between processors, memory subsystems, and I/O subsystems. Operating Systems that support the SLIT can use this information to improve performance by allocating resources and workloads more efficiently.
With the System Management Driver loaded, the Automatic Server Recovery feature allows the system to automatically reboot if the server locks up.
If Automatic Server Recovery is enabled, this selection sets the time to wait before rebooting the server in the event of an operating system crash or server lockup.

When Enabled, the system will attempt a graceful shutdown due to fan failures or removals which takes the system to below the minimum number of required fans or when the temperature increases beyond a pre-set threshold. When Disabled, the system will continue to operate until the temperature reaches a point where the system must be powered off immediately to prevent damage to hardware components.
Wake-On-LAN (WOL) allows the server to be powered on remotely when it receives a special packet. This feature requires a NIC, NIC driver and Operating System that are WOL-capable.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: After enabling Wake-on-LAN, remove all power cords before adding or removing any adapters. Some adapters can cause the system to power on when added or removed.

feature.feature_help_text: POST Error Response: Enabled: halt at an F1 prompt. Disabled: bypass the F1 prompt. Delayed: delay at the F1 prompt for 20 seconds.

Disabling this feature disables the momentary power button functionality. This feature does not affect the 4 second power button override. Also, this feature does not affect the remote power control functionality.

This feature configures the server to automatically power on when AC power is applied to the system. By default, the system will return to its previous power state when AC power is restored after an AC power loss. This option allows overriding this behavior such that the system will either power on or remain off when power is reapplied.

This feature will delay the server from turning on for the desired time. Pressing the power button, using the iLO 4 Virtual Power Button, Wake-ON LAN events and RTC Wake-up events will override the delay and immediately turn on the server. This allows staggering when servers power-up after a power loss to prevent power usage spikes.
Input a message to be viewed during POST.

This option allows the enabling of the Trusted Platform Module and BIOS secure startup. When enabled, the TPM is fully functional. When disabled, the TPM will be visible to software, but functionality will be limited.

This option provides the ability to hide the TPM from the operating system. When the TPM is hidden, BIOS secure startup is disabled, and the TPM will not respond to any commands from software. This option is intended to be used to remove the TPM feature from the system without removing the actual hardware.

This option allows enabling the BIOS to measure the PCI/PCI-e expansion (Option) ROM code and store that measurement into the TPM. Operating systems or validation software which utilizes the measurements stored in the TPM may now detect modifications to PCI/PCI-e expansion ROM versions.

This option allows the user to reset the TPM to factory settings, clearing any assigned passwords, keys, or ownership data. Clearing the TPM may prevent the server from booting to a TPM-aware operating system if the operating system was utilizing the TPM`s measurements.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Clearing the TPM may prevent booting to an operating system utilizing the TPM functionality. When setting this option, TPM functionality will be set to disabled. After a TPM Clear operation, the user must manually re-enable the TPM.

feature.feature_help_text: This option allows disabling the Intelligent Provisioning functionality. When Disabled, this option prevents entering the Intelligent Provisioning environment by pressing F10 during server boot or via any other mechanism. This option must be Enabled to use Intelligent Provisioning functionality.

This feature allows for video and keystrokes to be redirected through the serial port prior to OS boot. This feature may interfere with non-terminal devices attached to the serial port. Set it to Disabled in this case. This option is only supported when the Serial Port settings are set to COM 1 or COM 2. BIOS Serial Console is not supported when the Serial Port is configured for COM 3. This feature is not supported under RBSU in Japanese mode.
This is the transfer rate at which data will be transmitted through the serial port.

This is a Windows Server 2008 feature that allows for emergency management console to be redirected through the serial port When making this selection for redirecting EMS through a network connection, there are two options: 1) If using ILO, select the value (COM1 or COM2) that corresponds to the resources assigned to the Virtual Serial Port in the System Options menu of RBSU. 2) When redirecting EMS through a physical serial port, select the value (COM1 or COM2) which corresponds to the resources assigned to the embedded serial ports in the System Options menu of RBSU.
feature.feature_warning_text: Note: EMS configuration options have changed. See F1 Help text or RBSU Users Guide for more information.

feature.feature_help_text: Auto Mode enables CLI mode automatically for ROM embedded utilites if the system detects a console connection through the serial port. Command-Line Mode always enables CLI mode for ROM embedded utilities.

feature.feature_warning_text: Warning: Selecting <Yes, Save> will immediately reboot the server to complete.

Warning: Choosing this option will erase the current user-defined default settings. Once these user defaults are deleted, they may only be restored manually. This will not revert to the Factory Defaults. Selecting <Yes, Erase> will immediately reboot the server to complete.

feature.feature_help_text: - Balanced Power and Performance: Provides the optimum settings to maximize power savings with minimal impact to performance for most Operating Systems and applications. - Minimum Power Usage: Enables power reduction mechanisms that may negatively affect performance. This mode will guarantee a lower maximum power usage by the system. - Maximum Performance: Disables all power management options that may negatively affect performance. - Custom: Automatically selected when individual power settings are modified. Setting this option here does not change anything.

This feature configures the Power Regulator for ProLiant support: - HP Dynamic Power Savings Mode: Automatically varies processor speed and power usage based on processor utilization. Allows reducing overall power consumption with little or no impact to performance. Does not require OS support. - HP Static Low Power Mode: Reduces processor speed and power usage. Guarantees a lower maximum power usage for the system. Performance impacts will be greater for environments with higher processor utilization. - HP Static High Performance Mode: Processors will run in their maximum power/performance state at all times regardless of the OS power managment policy. - OS Control Mode: Processors will run in their maximum power/performance state at all times unless the OS enables a power management policy.
feature.feature_warning_text: Note: Certain processors support only one power state and will always operate at their initialized frequency no matter what Power Regulator mode is selected

feature.feature_help_text: This feature allows configuring how the system will handle redundant power supply configurations. Balanced Mode will share the power delivery equally between all installed power supplies. All High Efficiency Mode options provide the most power efficient operation with redundant power supplies by keeping half of the power supplies in standby mode at lower power usage levels. The High Efficiency Mode options allow choosing which power supply will be placed in standby. Auto will choose between the odd or even power supply based on the server`s serial number in order to achieve a semi-random distribution with a group of systems.
This feature enables placing the Quick Path Interconnect (QPI) links into a low power state when the links are not being utilized. This will lower power usage with minimal performance impact.
This option allows the user to set the QPI Link frequency to a lower speed. Running at a lower frequency may reduce power consumption but may also impact system performance.

The QPI link between 2 processors has been tuned to provide the best performance for all known applications. The Balanced option is the default since it provides the best performance for nearly all conventional customer applications and benchmarks. The optimized for I/O option has been shown to increase bandwidth from I/O devices such as GPUs that rely on direct access to system memory.
feature.feature_warning_text: Warning, changing this setting from the balanced option can have a negative impact on system performance. The overwhelming majority of performance benchmarking shows that the balanced setting is the optimized setting for most conventional applications. Selecting the Optimized for I/O could have negative impact on memory performance.

feature.feature_name: Minimum Processor Idle Power Core State
feature.feature_help_text: This feature selects the processor`s lowest idle core power state (C-State) which the operating system will utilize. The higher the C-State, the lower the power usage of that idle state (Core C6 is the lowest power idle core state supported by the processor).

feature.feature_name: Minimum Processor Idle Power Package State
feature.feature_help_text: This feature selects the processor`s lowest idle package power state (C-state) which is enabled. The processor will automatically transition into package C-states based on the Core C-states which cores on the processor have transitioned to. The higher the package C-state, the lower the power usage of that idle package state (Package C6 (retention) is the lowest power idle package state supported by the processor).

This option configures several processor subsystems to optimize the processor`s performance and power usage. Balanced Performance provides optimum power efficiency and is recommended for most environments. Maximum Performance Mode should be used for environments that require the highest performance and lowest latency but are not sensitive to power consumption. Power Savings Mode should only be used in environments that are power sensitive and are willing to accept reduced performance.

This feature allows configuring the memory system to run memory at a lower maximum speed than what is supported by the installed processor and DIMM configuration. Setting this option to Auto will configure the system to run memory at the maximum speed supported by the system`s configuration.

This feature allows modifying the level of interleaving for which the memory system will be configured. Typically, higher levels of memory interleaving will result in maximum performance. However, reducing the level of interleaving can result in power savings.

If a PCI-Express device does not run properly at the speed that it was designed for, lowering the speed in which the device is running may address the problem. This option allows lowering the maximum PCI-express speed the server will allow PCI-express devices to operate at and may be useful in addressing issues with problematic PCI-express devices. Setting this value to Maximum Supported will configure the platform to run at the maximum speed supported by the platform or the PCI-e device (whichever is lower).

The Dynamic Power Savings Mode feature allows the System ROM to control processor performance and power states depending on the processor workload. This option allows configuring the response time for switching between these states. - The Fast setting is optimal for most workloads where low latency response to an increase in processor demand is a requirement. - The Slow setting is optimal for some workloads where a longer latency response to increases in processing demand is an acceptable tradeoff for reduced power consumption. Selecting this option may have a negative performance impact depending on the workload.

For Operating Systems that support the Processor Clocking Control (PCC) Interface, enabling this option allows the Operating System to request processor frequency changes even when the server has the Power Regulator option configured for Dynamic Power Savings Mode. For Operating Systems that do not support the PCC Interface or when the Power Regulator Mode is not configured for Dynamic Power Savings Mode, this option has no impact to system operation.

This option allows the user to disable the System ROM Power Calibration feature that is executed during the boot process. When disabled, the user can expect faster boot times but will not be able to enable a Dynamic Power Cap until this feature is re-enabled.

This option allows the user to increase the voltage of LVDIMMs to 1.5V to allow memory to operate at an increased frequency (in certain configurations). If configured to Optimized for Power LVDIMMs will run at 1.35V even if this requires memory to run at a lower frequency. Note: The system will not allow 1.35V operation unless all installed DIMMs in the system are LVDIMMs.

This option configures several memory parameters to optimize the memory subsystems performance and power usage. Balanced provides optimum power efficiency and is recommended for most environments. Maximum Performance Mode should be used for environments that require the highest performance and/or lowest latency but are not sensitive to power consumption.
